abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Health, Fertility and
            Nutrition Project is rated as unsatisfactory, sustainability
            as unlikely, institutional development impact as
            unsatisfactory, Bank performance as unsatisfactory, and
            Borrower performance as highly satisfactory. The project
            failed to achieve most of its objectives. The project's
            scope was well beyond the Government's implementation
            capacity. It was a highly risky endeavor in view of the
            circumstances prevailing in Cameroon during the
            implementation. The economic crisis of the late 1980s and
            early 1990s severely undermined the social fabric in
            Cameroon. The capacity of the construction industry was also
            devastated, and therefore architectural firms and
            contractors were unable to deliver their products. Some
            basic lessons were drawn: 1) It is important to be realistic
            concerning expectations and systems must be in place for
            measuring performance. 2) Project design should be simple,
            especially in sectors without prior experience in
            Bank-financed projects. 3) No institutional assessments had
            been carried out on ministries that are entrusted with
            implementation. 4) Project implementation arrangements
            should be in place prior to project approval. 5) All
            stakeholders must be consulted. 6) Close Bank supervision
            should be carried out with Bank managers involved in the process.
